claim: Nuclear power is considered one of the safer sources of energy, despite concerns about nuclear meltdowns.

supporting.text: Nuclear power plants have a lower fatality rate per unit of energy produced compared to fossil fuel-based energy sources.

attacks.text: Nuclear power plants have a lower fatality rate per unit of energy produced compared to fossil fuel-based energy sources.
The fatality rate comparison does not account for long-term health effects of radiation exposure from nuclear accidents or waste disposal.
Modern nuclear waste storage and safety protocols significantly mitigate long-term radiation risks, making them negligible compared to immediate fossil fuel pollution.
Fossil fuel fatalities are often due to mining and transportation accidents, which are not inherent to the energy production process like nuclear meltdowns.
Nuclear meltdowns are extremely rare due to advanced safety measures, whereas fossil fuel pollution is a constant and widespread hazard.

supporting.text: Modern nuclear reactors incorporate advanced safety features that significantly reduce the risk of meltdowns.

attacks.text: Modern nuclear reactors incorporate advanced safety features that significantly reduce the risk of meltdowns.
Even with advanced safety features, human error and natural disasters can still lead to catastrophic failures, as seen in Fukushima.
The Fukushima incident involved outdated reactor designs; modern reactors have passive safety systems that do not rely on human intervention.
Passive safety systems are not foolproof and can fail under extreme conditions not accounted for in design scenarios.
The high cost of building and maintaining nuclear reactors with advanced safety features makes them less economically viable compared to renewable energy sources.
Nuclear power provides a stable and high-capacity baseload energy supply, which renewables currently cannot match without large-scale storage solutions.

supporting.text: The long-term health and environmental impacts of nuclear accidents, such as Chernobyl and Fukushima, demonstrate significant risks associated with nuclear power.

attacks.text: The long-term health and environmental impacts of nuclear accidents, such as Chernobyl and Fukushima, demonstrate significant risks associated with nuclear power.
Modern nuclear reactors incorporate advanced safety features that make accidents like Chernobyl and Fukushima extremely unlikely.
Even with advanced safety features, human error and unforeseen natural disasters can still lead to catastrophic failures.
Regulatory oversight and strict operational protocols minimize the risk of human error in modern nuclear plants.
The number of deaths per unit of energy produced is significantly lower for nuclear power compared to fossil fuels.
This statistic does not account for long-term health effects and environmental damage from nuclear accidents.

supporting.text: Nuclear power produces minimal air pollution compared to coal or natural gas, reducing respiratory diseases and premature deaths.

attacks.text: Nuclear power produces minimal air pollution compared to coal or natural gas, reducing respiratory diseases and premature deaths.
Nuclear power plants still produce radioactive waste, which poses long-term environmental and health risks if not managed properly.
Modern nuclear waste storage solutions, such as deep geological repositories, significantly mitigate the risks of radioactive contamination.
The construction and decommissioning of nuclear plants involve significant carbon emissions and environmental disruption.
Lifecycle analyses show that nuclear energy's carbon footprint is still far lower than fossil fuels over its operational lifetime.

supporting.text: The storage and disposal of nuclear waste pose unresolved environmental and safety challenges.

attacks.text: The storage and disposal of nuclear waste pose unresolved environmental and safety challenges.
Modern nuclear waste storage solutions, such as deep geological repositories, have been proven safe and effective in multiple studies.
Deep geological repositories are not yet operational in many countries, leaving interim storage as the primary method, which carries higher risks.
Interim storage facilities have robust safety records with minimal incidents over decades of use.

supporting.text: Nuclear energy has one of the lowest greenhouse gas emissions per kilowatt-hour among all energy sources.

attacks.text: Nuclear energy has one of the lowest greenhouse gas emissions per kilowatt-hour among all energy sources.
While nuclear energy has low operational emissions, the full lifecycle (mining, enrichment, waste disposal) still produces significant greenhouse gases.
Lifecycle emissions from nuclear are still far lower than fossil fuels and comparable to renewables when accounting for full supply chains.
The rare but catastrophic risks of nuclear accidents outweigh its emission benefits compared to safer renewables like wind/solar.
Modern reactor designs have passive safety systems making meltdowns physically impossible, while historical accident rates are far lower than fossil fuel deaths per kWh.
